name: Recycle or Not?
description: Rapid-fire item classification. How fast can you sort?

questions.explanation: Plastic water bottles (#1 PET) are widely recyclable. Empty, rinse, replace the cap.
questions.funFact: Recycling one plastic bottle saves enough energy to power a lightbulb for 3 hours.

questions.explanation: Banana peels are organic and compostable. They break down quickly in a compost bin.
questions.funFact: Banana peels can also be used to polish shoes and silverware.

questions.explanation: Aluminum cans are infinitely recyclable and one of the most valuable recyclables.
questions.funFact: A recycled aluminum can returns to the shelf as a new can in just 60 days.

questions.explanation: Styrofoam (polystyrene) is not accepted in most curbside recycling programs.
questions.funFact: Americans throw away 25 billion styrofoam cups every year.

questions.explanation: Cardboard is one of the most recycled materials. Flatten boxes before recycling.
questions.funFact: Over 80% of products sold in the US are packaged in corrugated cardboard.

questions.explanation: Batteries contain toxic chemicals and can cause fires. Take to hazardous waste drop-off.
questions.funFact: Batteries cause over 65% of fires at waste and recycling facilities.

questions.explanation: Glass is 100% recyclable and can be recycled endlessly without losing quality.
questions.funFact: Glass takes over 1 million years to decompose in a landfill.

questions.explanation: Plastic bags jam recycling machinery. Take to store drop-off or put in trash.
questions.funFact: The average plastic bag is used for only 12 minutes before being discarded.

questions.explanation: Newspaper is one of the most commonly recycled materials.
questions.funFact: Recycling one ton of newspaper saves 17 trees.

questions.explanation: Coffee grounds are excellent for composting. They add nitrogen to the soil.
questions.funFact: Starbucks gives away free used coffee grounds for composting.

questions.explanation: Most programs accept lightly soiled pizza boxes. Tear off heavily greased parts.
Donate wearable clothing. Worn-out textiles go in textile recycling bins.
questions.funFact: The average American throws away 81 pounds of clothing per year.

questions.explanation: Candy wrappers are metallized plastic film — multi-layer materials that cannot be recycled.
questions.funFact: Candy wrappers look metallic but are NOT aluminum — they're plastic with a thin metal coating.

questions.explanation: Paper egg cartons are recyclable. Styrofoam egg cartons go in trash.
Chip bags are metallized plastic film — the shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic.
Most toothpaste tubes are multi-layer plastic with residue — not recyclable curbside.
Ceramics melt at different temperatures than glass and ruin glass recycling batches.
Coffee pods are mixed materials (plastic + foil + coffee) — not recyclable curbside.
Most receipts are thermal paper coated with BPA — they contaminate recycling.
questions.funFact: Thermal receipts contain BPA, an endocrine disruptor.

questions.explanation: Natural cork is biodegradable and compostable. Synthetic corks go in trash.
Phones contain valuable metals and toxic materials. Take to e-waste recycling.
questions.funFact: There's more gold in a ton of phones than a ton of gold ore.

questions.explanation: Frozen food boxes are coated with a moisture barrier that prevents recycling.
Empty aerosol cans are recyclable as metal. Non-empty ones are hazardous waste.
Bubble wrap is plastic film that jams recycling machinery. Store drop-off or trash.
Juice pouches are multi-layer mixed materials — not recyclable curbside.
Prescription bottles are #5 PP plastic — recyclable in most programs. Remove the label first.
Parchment paper has a silicone coating that prevents recycling.
Razors are mixed materials (metal + plastic) — wrap blade for safety and trash.
Mirrors have a metallic coating that makes them incompatible with glass recycling.
Motor oil is a hazardous material. Take to auto parts stores or hazardous waste facilities.
questions.funFact: One gallon of used motor oil can contaminate 1 million gallons of water.

questions.explanation: Red Solo cups are #6 polystyrene — NOT recyclable in most curbside programs despite being rigid.
Wire hangers tangle in recycling machinery. Return to dry cleaners or trash.
Tetra Pak cartons are accepted in most curbside programs. Don't flatten them.
questions.funFact: Tetra Pak cartons are made of 75% paper, 20% polyethylene, and 5% aluminum.

questions.explanation: Remove the spiral wire (recycle as metal), then recycle the paper.
Dried latex paint can go in trash. Liquid latex paint must go to hazardous waste.
CFL bulbs contain mercury. Take to Home Depot, Lowe's, or hazardous waste drop-off.
questions.funFact: A single CFL bulb contains about 4mg of mercury.

questions.explanation: Black plastic can't be detected by optical sorting machines in recycling facilities.
questions.funFact: Optical sorters use near-infrared light to identify plastics — black absorbs the light, making it invisible.

questions.explanation: Pyrex has a different chemical composition than bottle glass and ruins recycling batches.
PLA cups are commercially compostable but NOT recyclable. Industrial compost only.
Shredded paper is recyclable but must be placed in a paper bag first so it doesn't scatter.
The small plastic window is fine — modern recycling handles it without removal.
Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks. Take to hazardous waste facility.
